algorithm_technique: Simulate manual multiplication: iterate through digits of both numbers, calculate products, handle carries, and store in a result array.
Reverse strings, perform multiplication similar to manual method, handle carries, and reverse the result.
Convert strings to integers, multiply, and convert back to string (violates constraints).
problem_summary_simple: Multiply two non-negative numbers represented as strings without using built-in big integer functions.
problem_summary_technical: Simulate grade-school multiplication by iterating through digits, calculating partial products, managing carries, and accumulating results in an array.
key_insights: The product of two numbers with lengths m and n will have a maximum length of m+n.
Each digit of num1 is multiplied by each digit of num2. The position of the product in the result array is determined by the sum of their indices.
Carries need to be handled carefully, propagating them to the left (higher significance) positions.
Reversing the strings simplifies index management for carries and final result construction.
The logic is identical to the first solution, just with reversed input strings.
The final result needs to be reversed again to get the correct order.
This is the most straightforward approach but explicitly disallowed by the problem statement.
It highlights the need to understand the underlying arithmetic operations when built-in functions are restricted.
